tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: Düstur: kavanin ve nizamat ve muahedat ile umuma ait mukavelat ve iradat-i seniyeyi muhtevidir.

From the SOAS copy, I photographed the sections on public education and the gendarmerie. the latter sections provide detailed information on wages and salaries. Apparently at least two editions were printed, as the one at SOAS differs in pagination from the copies at both StaBi and HTU. The StaBi copy bears an imprint on page 13: Istanbul, Maṭbaʿa-yi ʿĀmire, 1295 (aH, i.e. 1878/79, as the volume contains laws promulgated in 1879, it must be the latter date.)
- the date of publication is obviously wrong, as the volume contains laws from the years 1877 (e.g. law on municipalities)
SOAS edition contains sections on
- constitution (ḳānūn esāsī) (1ff)
- nāfiʿa ([public] benefits) (pp.509ff) and baladiye (pp.552ff)
- "vilāyāt baladiye ḳānūnu" law on provincial municipalities: 570-586
- "menāfiʿ-i ʿumūmiye için istimlāk-i emlāk ḳarārnāmesi" (decision concerning the expropriation / appropriation for the public benefit): 593ff

tss:note.title: contents SOAS
tss:note.comment:
the section on the judiciary contains supplements to the Penal Code
570-586: Law on Provincial Municipalities
593-8: expropriation of real-estate for public benefit (menāfiʿ-i ʿumūmiye)

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: Düstur: kavanin ve nizamat ve muahedat ile umuma ait mukavelat ve iradat-i seniyeyi muhtevidir.

<pb="538"/>

Art 3: responsibilities: construction of all buildings; broadening and establishment of roads; pavements and sewers; construction and repair of water conducts, both public and private [uqniyya al-māʾ al-ʿāmma wa al-khāṣṣa / ʿumūmī ve khuṣūsī ṣūyūları]; all the water issues under the responsibility of Waqfs; demolition of buildings considered dangerous by the municipality; estimations for the construction and repair of public buildings [al-kashf ʿalā al-abniyya al-amīriyya / ebniye-yi emīriye], covered by a special law; expropriation [istimlāk] of properties deemed necessary for the broadening of streets or public use [tawzīʿ al-ṭuruq wa al-manāfiʿ al-ʿāmma]; administration, exchange, repair, rent of real-estate in the property of the municipality; defence council in trials against the municipality; beautification of the town; maintenance of the property of the town the roads used for transport …; registration of all real-estate, its value, its revenues, names of proprietors, and a map of the property

<pb="539"/>

; registration of the population; registration of births and deaths [^3]; arrangement and extension of scales; upkeep of promenades, open places, and public gardens [al-ḥadāʾiq al-mukhtaṣa bi-l-ʿumūm / ve ʿumūma meḫṣūs bāghçeleri]; means of transport; establishment and improvement of fairs (bazaars) at convenient places; elaborating tariffs for coaches for goods and people as well as mounts; the good condition of coaches and mounts and their stations at the places assigned for this purpose; <note>different order of tasks in the French and Arabic versions</note> surveillance of everything concerning the police and public morality [al-adāb al-ʿāmma / ādāb-i ʿumūmiye]; surveillance of restaurants, cafés, casinos [qāʿāt al-malāʿib (biliyārde)], theaters, circuses, all places of public gatherings [wa kull maḥall yajtamaʿu ilayhi al-nās / ve mecmaʿ-i nās olān her bir maḥalle], promenades and bazars are supervised by the police <note>the following is not mentioned in the French translation</note> like the work of hired carriers at docks, prohibiting the people [al-nās] from washing [themselves] in open waters; sea baths; gangways and ferries etc; supervising the exactness of measures of weight, capacity, and length; purity, preparation, price, and weight of bread; cleanliness of ovens and workers at bakeries; prohibition of the sale of ill animals’ meat; construction of slaughterhouses at suitable locations outside the city’s interior; observation of health regulations concerning slaughterhouses and other sources of bead smells / unhealthy air; …; cleaning of all streets; public health in general; establishment of hospitals, asylums of the poor and foundlings, industrial schools, schools for blind and deaf children and orphans; care of sick among the poor, administration of existing facilities; … ; material for fighting fires and other hazards; guard for this material at special locations and nomination of personnel; furnishing work and tools to those not incapable to work in order to make begging gradually disappear ; burial of the poor; prohibition of brothels [the absence of conditions contravening public morals in places of gambling; ʿalā ʿadam wuqūʿ ḥālāt taghāyur al-adāb al-ʿumūmiyya fī maḥallāt al-alʿāb]; <pb="540"/>
collection of municipal revenues and their spending on its duties; measures against fraudsters; affairs of the guilds (esnaf).
<pb=“549”/>
Chapter 7: duties of the municipal sergeants /bailiffs [jāwūsh, jāwīshiyya], Art 56-61
Art 56:
- the municipality should appoint an appropriate number of inspectors of the bailiffs, they will act as their officers. the inspector’s powers are limited to the area of the appointing municipal council [i.e. not even the whole town, if more than one municipality exists]
Art 57:
- only Ottoman subjects can be appointed. they have to be literate, of good health, and have to have a clear criminal record. among those eligible, former soldiers are to be preferred. those illiterates currently employed cannot be re-appointed and shall be replaced
<pb=“550”/>
Art 58:
- whenever a person of these qualifications is found among the sergeants, only Ottoman subjects can be appointed to the vacant post of an inspector. They have to sit an exam to attest to their literacy.
Art 59:
- the inspector and the sergeants fulfill the duties bestowed upon them by the president, they will also, in general, apply the laws and regulations. they will gather in front of the municipal council, by a tezkere, those who deviate from these requirements and will need to seek the assistance of the police. In case of an incident, they will announce it to the nearest post of the police, and will immediately gather at the location of the incident and ensure that the water carriers work actively and that any damage is prevented.
Art 60:
- inspectors and bailiffs are allowed to enter khans, bathhouses, stores, shops, theaters (*tiyātrū* / *qāʿāt al-tashkhīṣ*), casinos (*cānbāz ḫāne* / *malāʿib*), cafés and similar places, casinos (*ġāzīnū*) and all places open to the public (*al-nās*)
Art 61:
- the sergeants patrol those areas only, to which they are assigned by their officers; they conduct their duties with all decency. They are prohibited to smoke pipes or cigarettes, to hold umbrellas or canes in their hands, to engage in conversations in the streets with anyone except for conducting their duties, and to sit inside cafes for rest.

Chapter 8: issues the municipality shall prohibit (belediyeçe memnūʿ olān eḥvāl)

Art 62 [very long article ]: the issues which the municipalities have to prohibit are: that the public (ehālī) or passersby do not throw garbage into the streets and on the grounds; that the copper instruments in restaurants and small cooking stands are tinned; that washing, towels, burnous [coat] etc. in [public] bathhouses are not dirty; that water and sullage does not flow from the houses and stores into the streets; that chimneys are not lower than the roof-tops; that sewers and water pipes are not opened without prior authorisation from the municipality

<pb=“551”/>

; that sewage canals, public or private (ʿumūmī ve ḫuṣūṣī) water canals, or gas piping are to obstructed by anyone; that one does not transport without cover fresh skins on the back of pack animals; that one does not obstruct / block public roads (yol üzerinde) through pedestals, barrels, “zanbils”, baskets, bowls, “kouffes”, boxes and crates, either empty or full; that no one leashes[?] “mangals” or storefront shutters in front of shops / magazines; that one does not extend the capacity of the shop under the pretext of displaying his merchandise; that, without a special permit from the municipality, no one places … in front of cabarets, cafés or similar places, chairs or stepladders to provide seats for the clients; and this regardless of the width of the street and even if nothing opposes this encroachment; that no one sells his merchandise or commodities/food in the streets, including erecting stalls, large pedestals, or tents; that one does not prepare “kebab” or other dishes in front of stores, on stoves or <pb=“82”> on “mangals”; that one does not use high roof gutters and pipes for the drainage of dirty pans; that one does not leave holes from wells or drains in the street, or any other objects that could prevent circulation; or that one does not transport [what?] in open containers ; that one does not slaughter sheep, oxen or buffaloes weak or sick, lambs of less than two months and calves less than four months; that one does not hunt or or sell the results of hunting between 15 August and the end of February; that one does not sell chickens, turkeys, geese, and other poultry after their chest is inflated [?]; that no one discharges meet or rotten fish, not yet rip or rotten fruits, prepared dishes or food, coffee, butter or other faulty items[^9], or bread of wrong weight or improper dough, into the stores or the streets; that the tents of stores are less than five pics high, and that they are not left standing over night; that does not cut wood in the streets in a manner obstructing circulation; that one does not walk animals on the sidewalks;

<pb=“552”>
that one does not race camels through the streets; that one does not lead loaded pack animals through the streets without one being tied to the other; that one does not ride loaded pack animals, or strike them; that planking and iron girders transported do not damage the pavement; that one does not transport charges at night through unlit streets; that one does not use lame, hurt or disabled pack animals; that one does not load more than 120 okka on a camel and 60 okka on healthy donkeys; that one does not store in shops or khans any objects dangerous to public health, such as fresh hides, bones, horns, rags and other objects of this kind; that one does not throw manure on the streets or at the foot of the walls; [… obstruction of roads …]; that one does not prepare or sell on pedestals (tabla) erected on the streets meatballs (kefte) and kebab; that one does not conserve wood chips or dray hayt, or any other inflammable material, or all other dirty objects and those endangering public health, in bakers’ stores or Simitcis, which do not have a basement, or in any other place not allowed by the municipality; that one does not let free or walk cows, oxen, sheep, goats or other animals through streets or in areas where the municipality does not allow it; that one does not tie sheep or other animals in front of stores; finally, that one does not bathe in the open sea.

Chapter 9: issues the municipality shall enforce (belediyece icrāsı lāzım gelen eḥvāl)
Art 63: any construction materials for buildings shall be placed in the garden or court of this building or on a nearby location with the consent of the proprietor; if this is impossible, they can be stored in front of the construction site on an area of one pic or large surrounded by a wooden fence. All rubble, stones etc. to be found in the street as a result of an incident, have to be immediately removed by the owners of the building; an enclosure wall or wooden fence has to be erected around the grounds. Any canals etc. opened for works, have to be closed after the work is finished and repaved; if this cannot be done within one day, the proprietor has to light the site a night with a lamp/lantern; burial pits will be dug in a manner approved by the municipal physician; abandoned wells or any other opening to be found, have to be immediately covered under the supervision of the municipality.
Butcheries have to be cleaned every day; meat is not to be stored without cover, but to be kept in cabinets on iron lattices which do not let the flies in, or they have to be covered with a fine mesh.

<pb=“553”>
The municipalities can also care for all issues of this matter, which might be of their interest.
Art 64: Measures and weights will generally be fair and bear the official seal. The objects and foodstuffs sold by merchants [weighting] less then five okra have to be measured absolutely accurately on the scale; for larger quantities a steelyard is permissible for wighting.

Chapter 10: penalties
Art 65: the requirements of Chapter III of the Criminal Code will be applied for transgressions of the provisions in this act and the municipal bylaws
Art 66
Art 67: the inspectors and sergeants who neglect their duties will be, on the first time, reprimanded by the municipal council; the second time, the will have to pay a fine equalling one month’s pay; the third time, they will be dismissed from the service and banned from any future service with the municipality,
END OF LAW
menāfiʿ-i ʿumūmiye için istimlāk-i emlāk niẓāmnāmesi
Düstur: kavanin ve nizamat ve muahedat ile umuma ait mukavelat ve iradat-i seniyeyi muhtevidir.

tss:note.title: supplement to the law concerning "public buildings"
tss:note.quotation: ebniye-yi mīriye ve vaḳfiye inşāʾāt ve taʿmīrātı ḥaḳında olan niżāmnāmesniñ on altıncı mādesi maḳāmına ḳāyım olmaḳ üzere māde-yi niżāmiye

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: The printing press is located at the Sublime Porte, at the Abū al-Saʿūd Street 72.
printed at another printing press than the copy held at SOAS

tss:note.title: provision of public health
tss:note.comment: contains inter alia a section on municipal doctors / physicians

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: printed at another printing press than the copy held at SOAS

tss:note.title: Art 1: five categories of street widths
Art 5
tss:note.comment:
It is not allowed to erect buildings in the vicinity of places of worship, ports, squares for the public (ʿumūma ʿāʾid meydānlar) etc. and lands for the public benefit (menāfiʿ-i ʿāmme için) [important: public works would be menāfiʿ-i ʿumūmiye]. It is prohibited to change the width of those places.
- Art 5: it is not permitted to anyone to construct buildings in the free spaces (al-fusḥāt al-matrūka) around places of worship (al-maʿābid) and public places (al-fusḥāt al-ʿumūmiyya), parks, and other metruke lands for public benefit (li-l-manāfiʿ al-ʿumūmiyya). and it is prohibited to change the width of those places in any aspect. and if the municipality saw the need to change existing old buildings lining those open spaces without interfering with the amount of space allocated to them, they can do so with an sanctioning imperial irade only
tss:note.quotation:
Maʿābid ḥevelilerile iskelelerde ve ʿumūma ʿāʾid meydānlar ile mesīrelerde ve-l-ḥāṣıl menāfiʿ-i ʿāmme için terek olunmuş olan yerlerde ebniye inşāsıve bū maḥallerin her ne ṣūretle olur ise olsun ḫuṣūṣiyete taḥvīli memnūʿdur.
Ancak bu misillū mahallerin fevkalāde olarak tağyir ve tanzimine lüzum görüldüğü halde Babı āliden istizan olunacaktır.

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya

tss:note.title: Art 35 (street signs and numbers)
tss:note.comment:
- signs of street / square names, numbers of buildings facing the street, announcement of broadening works.
- house numbers have to be paid for by the owner of the house, and be checked twice a year by the authorities
construction signs have to announce any works scheduled by the owners of houses, sign to be paid for by the owner

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya

According to Lisān al-Ḥāl 959 (26 May 1887) and Thamarāt al-Funūn (30 May 1887), the second volume was published in May 1887. Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal al-Ṭarabulusī
containing Arabic translations of the press law, such as the 1857 regulation (194-195)

- both laws state that one cannot practice medicine or pharmacy without holding a proper degree form an Ottoman medical college or a foreign university

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya

tss:note.title: Art 14
tss:note.comment: any owner of a newspaper who writes something contravening public morals (shayʾan mughāyiran li-l-adāb al-ʿumūmiyya aw maḥāsin al-akhlāq al-maḥalliyya), or who insulted one of the many cults / religions (adyān aw madhāhib) in the empire, is liable to a payment of £T 1-25 at Ps 100 or imprisonment from one week to three months.

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya
al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya

tss:note.title: Art 9: extend of works
tss:note.comment:
- a day's work is at least 9 pics of pavement (turāb) lining the sides of the streets, or 2,5 pics of road works (taking the stones and breaking them up and lying them on the street)
- a day's work of a beast of burden is to transport the whole stones from the warehouse/ quarry to the construction site.

tss:note.title: Art 8
tss:note.comment:
- liable inhabitants are established by census. everyone has to serve 20 days in five years or pay an exemption fee.
- beasts of burden

tss:note.title: Art 14
tss:note.comment: - at the end of five years every settlement has to prepare accounts of the days of corvéed labour actually worked. if it differs from the legally allotted number of days, the inhabitants (ahālī) have the right / duty to compensate the numbers during the next five years

tss:note.title: Art 1
tss:note.comment:
Art 1: the law is concerned with the roads in the empire. the highest class are the roads from the provincial capitals to Istanbul.
[apparently the law is only concerned with the roads outside of any settlement]

tss:note.title: Art 7: corvée labour in cities, towns, and villages
tss:note.comment: those in the age of manual labour (fī sinn al-aʿmāl) are liable to crovée for road works, they can either work themselves, pay an exemption fee, or provide beasts of burden

tss:note.title: Art 11
tss:note.comment: - extend of works and scheduled dates are established annually by the council of the sancak

tss:note.title: Art 15
tss:note.comment: - cities, towns, or villages cannot order road works at locations more than 12 hours' distance, but by special order from the Sublime Porte

tss:note.title: Art 10
tss:note.comment: - certain people are exempt from the works: clergy, rabbis, teachers at schools (makātib wa madāris), soldiers and gendarmes under arms

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: niẓām al-amlāk allatī tashtarī li-ajlī al-manāfiʿ al-ʿumūmiyya
al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya

tss:note.title: Art 1: definition of public works / manāfiʿ ʿumūmiyya
tss:note.quotation: al-ashiyāʾ al-shāmila li-l-manāfiʿ al-ʿumūmiyya … tawsīʿ al-ṭuruq

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: taʿlīmāt tartīb al-majlis al-baladiyya fī al-wilāyāt
al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya
According to Sharif 2014:46, the law was called "Ṣūrat tartīb majālis al-dawāʾir al-baladiyya al-latī tatashakkal fī almudun wa-l-qaṣabāt dākhil al-wilāya wa-waẓāʾif maʾmūrīha"
Formation of Municipal Councils in the Provinces
taʿlīmāt waẓāʾif al-dawāʾir al-baladiyya fi al-wilāyāt
al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya
Tasks of Municipal Councils in the Provinces
al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya

tss:note.title: Art 3
tss:note.comment: ovens that shall be turned into a bakery of bread, need to apply to the baladiyya, quite expensive

tss:note.title: Art 4
tss:note.comment: those ovens which do not commence work within two months of obtaining the permit to bake bread, will be punished.

tss:note.title: Art 2
tss:note.comment: all those engaged in the bread trade equally need a permit from the baladiyya and have one month to obtain one from the announcement of this law. the permit costs between Ps 50-100 according to the means of the applicant

tss:note.title: Art 1
tss:note.comment: everyone running a bakery (khabbāza) needs a permit from the baladiyya

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya
Nawfal's translation follows Naqqāsh's. The wording is lightly different.

tss:note.title: Art 5
tss:note.comment: - metrūke lands are of two types. The first are those metruke lands for the entirety of people (li-ajli ʿumūm al-nās). these are general / public roads (al-ṭarīq al-ʿāmm). The second type are metrūke lands "belonging" to all inhabitants of a village (al-makhṣūṣa ilā ʿumūm ahālī al-qariyya) or a town, or villages or towns. These are the pastures that belong to the inhabitants of villages or towns.

tss:note.title: Art 5
tss:note.comment: - metrūke lands are of two types. The first are those metruke lands for the entirety of people (li-ajli ʿumūm al-nās). these are general / public roads (al-ṭarīq al-ʿāmm). The second type are metrūke lands "belonging" to all inhabitants of a village (al-makhṣūṣa ilā ʿumūm ahālī al-qariyya) or a town, or villages or towns. These are the pastures that belong to the inhabitants of villages or towns.

tss:note.title: Art. 96
tss:note.comment: places used for gatherings of all people / the public (makhṣūṣan mundhu al-qadīm ilā majmūʿ ʿumūm ahālī) of a village since the old ages, cannot be built over with any building, cannot be sold, and cannot be registered

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya

According to Lisān al-Ḥāl 959 (26 May 1887) and Thamarāt al-Funūn (30 May 1887), the second volume was published in May 1887. Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal al-Ṭarabulusī, according to the frontispiece, he had been the bashkātib of the customs in ʿArabistān. Khalīl Efendi al-Khūrī was the director of publications in the province.
AUB owns at least three (sic) copies of the first volume (349.56 T93dA v.1 c.1; 349.56 T93dA v.1 c.2; and CA 349.56:T93dA:v.1).
The University of Indiana's copy is available from HathTrust, with the scan missing some pages: 74-75, 161, 178-179, 224-227, 426-427, 448-449, 528-529, 550-551, 554-555
commences with the imperial decree promulgating the tanzimat reforms, 26 Shaʿ 1255 [4 Nov 1839]

2-4khaṭṭ al-humāyūn (26 Shaʿ 1255) [4 Nov 1839]
14-44 qānūn al-arāḍī wa dhayluhu
44-51niẓām al-ṭābū wa dhayluhu
68-72niẓām istimlāk al-tabaʿa al-ajnabiyya li-l-imlāk
323-373niẓām al-jizāʾ al-humāyūnī
397-niẓam idāra al-wilāya al-ʿumūmiyya
al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya

373 Art 260, Penal Code
- those who disturb the tranquility of the inhabitants or tear down placards posted by order of the authorities will be punished with a payment of 10-15 Beshliks [and 3 days to one week in prison; this is not mentioned in this translation]
- Art 261: missing!

tss:note.title: Art. 260
tss:note.comment: those who disturb the tranquility of the inhabitants (rāḥar al-ahālī) or tear down placards posted by order of the authorities will be punished with a payment of 10-15 Beshliks [and 3 days to one week in prison; this is not mentioned in this translation]

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya

tss:note.title: Art. 3: kazas
tss:note.comment: Every sancak is divided into kazas, which all have a single kaimakamiye / Ḳāʾimaḳāmiyya which is located in the main town (qaṣba)

tss:note.title: Art. 4: villages / qurā
tss:note.comment: Kazas are divided into villages / qurā, administered by a municipality (baladiyya)

tss:note.title: Art. 1 centralised government
tss:note.comment: the administration of the province is centralised and located at a single centre

tss:note.title: Preamble
tss:note.comment: The divisions of the Ottoman Empire are called vilayet

tss:note.title: Art. 5: division of cities
tss:note.comment: towns and cities are divided into units of 50 households (bayt). These units form quarters (maḥallas) and are considered as villages in the sense of this law

tss:note.title: Art. 2: sancaks
tss:note.comment: The administration of a district (sancak) is located inside the very district and at its central city. It is called the mutaṣarrifiyya

tss:characteristics.tss:characteristic: al-Dustūr: tarjamahu min al-lughat al-turkiyya ilā al-ʿarabiyya Nawfal Niʿmat Allāh Nawfal bāshkātib kamāruk ʿArabistān sābiqan; bi-murājaʿa wa tadqīq Khalīl al-Khūrī mudīr maṭbūʿāt wilāyat Sūriyya
